questions.text: Meiosis occurs in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adult ovary

Explanation:

  • Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as part of oogenesis. In females, during fetal development, primary oocytes are arrested in prophase I of meiosis. These oocytes remain in this arrested state until puberty, when they resume meiosis. Meiosis continues during ovulation, leading to the formation of a secondary oocyte, which is arrested in metaphase II until fertilization.


Incorrect Options:

Adrenal (option A): This is incorrect because meiosis does not occur in the adrenal glands. The adrenal glands are involved in hormone production, not gametogenesis.

Prepubertal testis (option C): This is incorrect because meiosis in males begins at puberty, not before. In the prepubertal testis, germ cells undergo mitosis, not meiosis.

Hypothalamus (option D): This is incorrect because the hypothalamus is part of the brain that regulates various physiological processes, including hormone release. It does not participate in meiosis.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the normal vascular composition of the umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2 arteries and 1 vein

Explanation:

  • The umbilical cord contains two arteries that carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta, and one vein that carries oxygenated blood from the placenta back to the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1 artery and 2 veins: This is incorrect because the umbilical cord normally has two arteries and only one vein, not the other way around.

Option B - 1 vein and 1 artery: This represents an abnormal or incomplete vascular arrangement, often linked to congenital anomalies.

Option D - 2 arteries and 2 veins: The umbilical cord typically contains only one vein, so having two veins is not normal.

questions.text: The image shows a congenital cardiac defect. Abnormal development of which branch of aortic arch leads to this defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Left 6th aortic arch

Explanation:

The image illustrates Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), a congenital heart defect that occurs when the ductus arteriosus—originating from the left 6th aortic arch—fails to close after birth.

  • It creates a left-to-right shunt → Ooxygenated blood from the aorta flow into the pulmonary artery → Excessive pulmonary blood flow
  • This results in respiratory distress, cyanosis, and a machinery-like murmur, often worsening despite oxygen administration.

Pharyngeal Arch

Artery of Arch

First
  • Maxillary artery

Second
  • Hyoid artery
  • Stapedial artery

Third
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery

Fourth
  • Arch of aorta (left side) (Option D ruled out)
  • Subclavian artery (right side) (Option A ruled out)

Sixth
  • Ductus arteriosus (left side) (Option B)
  • Pulmonary artery (right side) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which structure is formed by the structure indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nucleus pulposus:

Explanation:

  • The arrow points to the Notochord, an embryonic midline structure that acts as the primitive axial skeleton, induces neural tube formation, and later forms the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc in adults.

  • Nucleus pulposus: The core of the intervertebral disc, derived from the embryonic notochord, and functions to absorb spinal compression and provide flexibility.
  • Notochord Formation:
    • Formation of the primitive streak
    • Migration of mesodermal cells through the primitive node
    • Formation of the notochordal process
    • Formation of the notochordal plate
    • Detachment of the notochordal plate
    • Rolling into the definitive notochord

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Annulus (Option A) refers to the annulus fibrosus, the outer fibrous ring of the intervertebral disc, which does not originate from the notochord, but from mesoderm (sclerotome).
  • Neural tube (Option C) forms from the ectoderm, induced by signals from the notochord, but it is not formed by the notochord itself.
  • Septum transversum (Option D) contributes to the diaphragm and develops from mesoderm, unrelated to the notochord.

questions.text: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore at 25th day leads to
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anencephaly:

  • This is a neural tube defect where the rostral (cephalic) end of the neural tube fails to close, resulting in the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp. Sadly, it's not compatible with life.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Craniorachischisis: This occurs when both the cranial and caudal ends of the neural tube fail to close. It's a severe form of neural tube defect where the brain and spinal cord are exposed.

Option B - Spina Bifida: This typically results from the incomplete closure of the caudal neuropore. It's a defect in the development of the spinal cord, but in this scenario, the rostral end is affected.

Option D - Hydranencephaly: This is a condition where the cerebral hemispheres are largely or completely absent, replaced by cerebrospinal fluid. It's not specifically associated with the failure of the rostral neuropore closure.

questions.text: Which of the following arises from 6th pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ductus arteriosus

Explanation:

  • The ductus arteriosus arises from the sixth pharyngeal arch
  • The ductus arteriosus is a fetal blood vessel that connects the pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta, allowing a portion of oxygenated blood to bypass the developing fetal lungs.
  • This shunt helps direct oxygenated blood towards the systemic circulation while the lungs are not yet fully functional in the prenatal period.

Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

Muscles of arch

(Options A, B, and D)

First

 

Maxillary (Sensory) and mandibular (Motor and sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve

Maxillary artery
  • Meckel's cartilage
    • Malleus
    • Incus
    • Anterior ligament of malleus
    • Sphenomandibular ligament
  • Mandible

  • Palatine

  • Tensor palati

 

All are migratory except T. tympani

Second

Facial nerve

The cartilage of the second arch (Reichert’s) forms the

All are migratory except stapedius, stylohyoid

Glossopharyngeal nerve

Stylopharyngeus

  • Corniculate

All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid

questions.text: Which of the following develops from the dorsal mesogastrium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Falciform ligament

Explanation:

 

  • The spleen develops from the dorsal mesogastrium.
  • During embryonic development, the spleen forms from mesenchymal cells within the mesoderm, specifically in the dorsal mesogastrium.

Falciform ligament (Option A): The falciform ligament arises from the ventral mesogastrium during embryonic development.

Lesser omentum (Option C): The lesser omentum does not develop from the dorsal mesogastrium but rather from the ventral mesogastrium.

Liver (Option D): The liver does not develop directly from the dorsal mesogastrium. It forms in association with the ventral mesogastrium.

questions.text: Which of the following is the 1st to be formed by the migration of the epiblast along the primitive streak?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endoderm

 

Explanation:

  • During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak to form the three germ layers.
  • The first cells to migrate displace the hypoblast and form the endoderm.
  • Subsequent migration leads to mesoderm formation, while non-migrating epiblast cells remain as ectoderm.

Gastrulation and Germ Layer Formation

Stage

Description

Primitive Streak Formation

Forms along the midline of the epiblast, marking the site of cell migration.

Endoderm Formation

The first wave of migrating epiblast cells replaces the hypoblast to form the definitive endoderm, which later gives rise to the gut and associated organs.

Mesoderm Formation

Subsequent migration of epiblast cells forms the mesoderm, which differentiates into structures like the cardiac mesoderm and notochord.

Ectoderm Formation

Epiblast cells that do not migrate remain as ectoderm, which later forms the epidermis and neural structures.

Cardiac mesoderm (Option B): Incorrect because it arises from the mesoderm, which forms after the endoderm.

Epidermis (Option C): Incorrect as it originates from ectoderm, which forms last.

Neural groove (Option D): Incorrect since it arises from the ectoderm later during neurulation, after gastrulation.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram showing the development of ovarian follicles.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antral follicle

Explanation:

  • Antral follicles are characterized by the presence of a fluid-filled cavity (antrum) surrounding the oocyte.
  • These follicles have multiple layers of granulosa cells, a well-developed theca interna and theca externa, and contribute to hormone production. The presence of the antrum differentiates them from primary follicles, which lack this cavity.

Development of Ovarian Follicles

Stage

Characteristics

Primordial follicle

Oocytes surrounded by a single layer of flattened granulosa cells. Dormant until puberty.

Primary follicle

Granulosa cells become cuboidal, zona pellucida begins forming around the oocyte. No antrum.

Secondary follicle

Multiple layers of granulosa cells and theca cells form. Early follicular development but no antrum yet.

Antral follicle

Fluid-filled antrum appears, granulosa and theca cells differentiate. Prepares for ovulation.

Graafian follicle

Fully matured, large antrum, ready for ovulation.

Corpus luteum

Formed after ovulation, secretes progesterone to support pregnancy. If there is no fertilization, it degenerates.

Primary follicle (Option A): Incorrect because primary follicles lack an antrum and have a single or multilayered granulosa cell arrangement.

Primordial follicle (Option C): Incorrect because primordial follicles are the earliest stage, with a single layer of flattened granulosa cells and no antrum.

Corpus luteum (Option D): Incorrect because the corpus luteum is a post-ovulatory structure that does not resemble a developing follicle and lacks an antrum.

questions.text:
What are the derivatives of the marked cells? 

 

1. Odontoblasts 

2. Sympathetic chain 

3. Melanocytes 

4. Nephrogenic cord 

5. Bulbus cordis 

6. Conotruncal septum
questions.solution:
Answer: C) 1,2,3,6

 

Explanation:

Neural crest cells (NCC) are a group of cells that arise from the ectoderm during early development and give rise to a wide variety of structures in the body. The derivatives of neural crest cells include:

  1. Odontoblasts:
    • Neural crest cells contribute to the development of odontoblasts, which are responsible for the formation of dentin in teeth.
  2. Sympathetic chain:
    • Neural crest cells give rise to the sympathetic ganglia and the sympathetic chain, which is part of the autonomic nervous system.
  3. Melanocytes:
    • Neural crest cells also give rise to melanocytes, which are the pigment-producing cells in the skin.
  4. Conotruncal septum:
    • Neural crest cells contribute to the formation of the conotruncal septum, which is important in the proper separation of the pulmonary trunk and aorta during heart development.

 

Nephrogenic cord (4): The nephrogenic cord is derived from the mesoderm, not the neural crest cells. It forms the precursors to the kidneys.

 

Bulbus cordis (5): The bulbus cordis is part of the heart and is derived from the mesoderm. It contributes to the formation of the right ventricle and the outflow tract of the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Retinal pigment epithelium

 

Explanation:

  • Neural crest cells (NCCs) give rise to a wide variety of structures, including components of the peripheral nervous system, connective tissue, and pigment cells.
  • The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), however, arises from the neural ectoderm, not from neural crest cells.
  • The RPE is derived from the outer layer of the optic cup, which forms from the neural tube.

Derivatives of Neural Crest Cells

Structure

Neural Crest Origin

Ciliary muscles

Derived from neural crest

Ciliary ganglion

Derived from neural crest

Melanocytes

Derived from neural crest

Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

Derived from neural ectoderm

Ciliary muscles (Option A): incorrect because they arise from neural crest cells, forming part of the intraocular muscles.

Ciliary ganglion (Option C): incorrect because it is a parasympathetic ganglion derived from neural crest cells.

Melanocytes (Option D): incorrect because melanocytes originate from neural crest cells, contributing to pigmentation in various tissues.

questions.text: On what is the SRY gene located?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Y chromosome short arm

Explanation:

  • The SRY gene (Sex-determining Region Y) is located on the short arm (p arm) of the Y chromosome, specifically at Yp11.2. It plays a critical role in initiating male sex determination by triggering the development of testes.

Sex differentiation

Male Development:

  • SRY Gene:
    • Located on the Y chromosome; initiates the development of testes.
    • Activates downstream genes like SOX9 and SF1, which are essential for Sertoli and Leydig cell differentiation.
  • Testosterone Effects:
    • Testosterone, secreted by Leydig cells, stimulates the mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts to form male reproductive structures (e.g., epididymis, vas deferens, and seminal vesicles, and ejaculatory duct).
  • Dihydrotestosterone (DHT):
    • Promotes the development of external genitalia (penis and scrotum).
  • Müllerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS):
    • Known as Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)
    • Secreted by Sertoli cells; causes the regression of the paramesonephric (Müllerian) ducts, preventing the development of female reproductive structures.

Female Development:

  • Absence of SRY Gene:
    • Without the SRY gene, the gonads develop into ovaries.
  • Paramesonephric (Müllerian) Ducts:
    • Develop into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper 1/3rd of the vagina.
  • External Genitalia:
    • Develop in the absence of testosterone, forming the clitoris, labia minora, and labia majora.

questions.text: Absence or mutation of SRY gene results in ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Agenesis of testis

Explanation:

  • The SRY gene (Sex-determining Region Y gene) is located on the Y chromosome and plays a crucial role in the development of male sex characteristics. If the SRY gene is absent or mutated, it can lead to a failure in the development of testes, resulting in agenesis of testis.

Sex differentiation

Male Development:

  • SRY Gene:
    • Located on the Y chromosome; initiates the development of testes.
    • Activates downstream genes like SOX9 and SF1, which are essential for Sertoli and Leydig cell differentiation.
  • Testosterone Effects:
    • Testosterone, secreted by Leydig cells, stimulates the mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts to form male reproductive structures (e.g., epididymis, vas deferens, and seminal vesicles, and ejaculatory duct).
  • Dihydrotestosterone (DHT):
    • Promotes the development of external genitalia (penis and scrotum).
  • Müllerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS):
    • Known as Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)
    • Secreted by Sertoli cells; causes the regression of the paramesonephric (Müllerian) ducts, preventing the development of female reproductive structures.

Female Development:

  • Absence of SRY Gene:
    • Without the SRY gene, the gonads develop into ovaries.
  • Paramesonephric (Müllerian) Ducts:
    • Develop into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper 1/3rd of the vagina.
  • External Genitalia:
    • Develop in the absence of testosterone, forming the clitoris, labia minora, and labia majora.

 

Undescended testis (Option B): Undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is usually due to issues with testicular descent, not a lack of the SRY gene.

Hydrocele testis (Option C): Hydrocele is a condition where there is fluid accumulation around the testis, which is unrelated to the SRY gene.

None of the above (Option D): This is incorrect because the absence or mutation of the SRY gene does lead to agenesis of testis, as mentioned above.

questions.text: Which of the following structures develop from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ductus arteriosus

Explanation:

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side specifically develops into the ductus arteriosus and a portion of the right and left pulmonary arteries.

Pharyngeal Arch

Artery of Arch

First

Maxillary artery

Second

Hyoid artery, Stapedial artery

Third

Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery (Option C)

Fourth

Arch of aorta (left side), Subclavian artery (right side) (Option A&D)

Sixth

Ductus arteriosus (left side), Pulmonary artery (right side)

questions.text: Implantation occurs on which day post fertilization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 5

Explanation:

Implantation begins around Day 5 post-fertilization when the blastocyst reaches the uterus and starts attaching to the endometrial lining. The process continues over the next few days, with full implantation completed by Day 9-10.

Fertilisation to Implantation:

Stage

Day (Post-Fertilization)

Key Event

Fertilization

Day 0

Sperm fertilizes oocyte in ampulla of fallopian tube

Zygote Formation

Day 1

Single-cell zygote undergoes cleavage

Morula Formation

Day 3-4

16-cell stage compacted into a solid ball

Blastocyst Formation

Day 5

Fluid-filled cavity forms; blastocyst reaches the uterus

Implantation Begins

Day 5-6

Blastocyst attaches to the endometrium

Trophoblast Invasion

Day 6-8

Syncytiotrophoblast formation, hCG secretion begins

Complete Implantation

Day 9-10

Blastocyst is fully embedded in the endometrial lining

questions.text: Post ovulation the oocyte is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase-2:

  • After ovulation, the oocyte is a secondary oocyte that is arrested in metaphase of the second meiotic division. It completes the second meiotic division only if fertilization occurs. If fertilization does not take place, the oocyte will degenerate.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primary oocyte arrested in prophase-1:

  • The primary oocyte is arrested in prophase of the first meiotic division. This arrest occurs before ovulation. During ovulation, the oocyte has already completed the first meiotic division to become a secondary oocyte.

Option B - Primary oocyte arrested in prophase-2:

  • The primary oocyte is not arrested in prophase-2; it is arrested in prophase-1. Prophase-2 arrest does not occur until after the first meiotic division is completed.

Option C - Secondary oocyte arrested in prophase-2:

  • The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase-2, not prophase-2. Prophase-2 arrest is not a correct description for the secondary oocyte's state after ovulation.

questions.text: The covering of an omphalocele is derived from which layer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amnion:

  • Amnion: The covering of an omphalocele is derived from the amnion. An omphalocele is a congenital defect where abdominal organs herniate through the umbilical ring into the base of the umbilical cord, and these herniated organs are covered by a membrane composed of amnion on the outside and peritoneum on the inside.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chorion: The chorion is another fetal membrane, but it does not contribute to the covering of an omphalocele.

Option C - Mesoderm: The mesoderm is a germ layer involved in the formation of various tissues and organs but not in the direct covering of an omphalocele.

Option D - Endoderm: The endoderm forms the lining of the gastrointestinal tract and other internal structures but does not contribute to the covering of an omphalocele.

questions.text:
Identify the marked structure:
 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primitive streak

 

Explanation:

The primitive streak is the first structure to form during gastrulation, appearing as a linear midline thickening in the epiblast. It acts as the site of cell migration, leading to the formation of the three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm).

Primitive Streak and Its Role in Gastrulation

Stage

Description

Formation

Appears on day 15 of development as a linear thickening in the epiblast of the bilaminar disc.

Function

Acts as a site for epiblast cell migration, which forms the mesoderm and endoderm.

Regression

By the end of the 4th week, the primitive streak regresses, leaving behind the notochord and mesoderm.

Clinical Significance

If it fails to regress, it may lead to sacrococcygeal teratoma (tumor with all three germ layers).

Notochord (Option B): Incorrect because the notochord forms after the primitive streak from mesodermal cells.

Neural Groove (Option C): Incorrect because the neural groove forms later during neurulation, as the neural plate invaginates.

Secondary Neural Plate (Option D): Incorrect because it is involved in secondary neurulation (formation of the caudal neural tube), not in early gastrulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect related to the given image?

choices.text: Result from the aberrant migration of primordial germ cell

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prechordal plate anomaly

Explanation:

  • Sacrococcygeal teratomas are tumors that originate from primordial germ cells and are typically found at the base of the spine.
  • They are associated with the remnants of the primitive streak rather than the prechordal plate.

 

  • Teratomas mostly occur during the neonatal period and most of them are benign
  • Most common site- Sacrococcygeal region
  • Females > males
  • The risk of malignancy increases with age
  • It is thought to be derivative of the primitive streak

Clinical features:

  • External presacral mass with minimal intrapelvic presacral component
  • Symptoms include weakness, paralysis, and bladder or bowel dysfunction
  • Currarino Triad: Anorectal malformations + sacrococcygeal osseous defect + presacral mass

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • CT/MRI is done to detect intra-abdominal and intra-pelvic components.

Treatment:

  • Complete surgical excision of the tumor should be done
  • To avoid local recurrence - resection of the coccyx is done

 

Benign tumor of coccyx (Option A): Sacrococcygeal teratoma is a tumor that arises at the base of the spine, often from remnants of primitive tissue, and it can exhibit both benign(mostly) and malignant (few) characteristics.

Presence of teeth and hair (Option B): Teratomas can have any of the 3 germ layers (Endoderm, ectoderm or mesoderm) because primordial germ cells themselves are pluripotent cells.

Result from the aberrant migration of primordial germ cell (Option C): Abrupt migration of primordial germ cells may cause oropharyngeal teratoma and sacrococcygeal teratoma.

questions.text: Which of the following prevents polyspermy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cortical reaction:

  • This is a key mechanism to prevent polyspermy. Upon sperm penetration, cortical granules in the oocyte release their contents, which modify the zona pellucida (the layer surrounding the oocyte). This change creates a barrier that prevents additional sperm from binding and entering the oocyte, ensuring that only one sperm fertilizes the egg.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acrosome reaction:

  • Incorrect: The acrosome reaction is the process by which the sperm releases enzymes to penetrate the zona pellucida of the oocyte. It is crucial for sperm to access the egg but does not prevent polyspermy.

Option C - Zona reaction:

  • Incorrect: The zona reaction involves changes in the zona pellucida but is not the primary mechanism preventing polyspermy. It refers to the structural changes in the zona pellucida that occur after the cortical reaction.

Option D - Capacitation:

  • Incorrect: Capacitation is a physiological process that sperm undergo to gain the ability to fertilize an egg. It involves changes to the sperm's membrane and is necessary for fertilization but does not prevent polyspermy.

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Levator veli palatini:

This structure is not derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch. The levator veli palatini muscle is actually derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch. It forms part of the soft palate and helps elevate the soft palate during swallowing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medial pterygoids: The medial pterygoid muscles, from the 1st pharyngeal arch, aid in jaw movement during chewing, situated in the back of the oral cavity.

Option C - Lateral pterygoids: The lateral pterygoid muscles, from the 1st pharyngeal arch, assist in jaw movement, mainly in opening the mouth, situated in the oral cavity's lateral walls.

Option D - Tensor veli palatini: The tensor veli palatini muscle, from the 1st pharyngeal arch, is in the soft palate, helping control the Eustachian tube during swallowing and yawning.

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pre synaptic Secretory vesicles

  • In the given image , the structure marked with an asterisk in the electron micrograph represents pre-synaptic secretory vesicles. Secretory vesicles are membrane-bound organelles found within the pre-synaptic terminal of neurons. They play a crucial role in the process of neurotransmission.
  • Secretory vesicles store and transport neurotransmitters, which are chemical messengers that transmit signals between neurons or from neurons to target cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mitochondria: Mitochondria are responsible for energy production in the form of ATP and are not specifically involved in neurotransmission.

Option B - Golgi bodies: Golgi bodies modify, sort, and package proteins for secretion or delivery within cells. Although crucial for cellular transport, they aren't directly linked to neurotransmission.

Option C - Ribosomes: Ribosomes are cellular structures involved in protein synthesis and are not directly related to neurotransmission.

questions.text: Meissner corpuscles are present in:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Papillary dermis

  • Meissner corpuscles, also known as tactile corpuscles, are specialized sensory receptors involved in the perception of light touch and vibration. They are encapsulated nerve endings located within the dermis, specifically in the papillary dermis. The papillary dermis is the upper layer of the dermis, directly beneath the epidermis. It is characterized by its uneven surface due to the presence of dermal papillae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis, the deeper layer, lacks Meissner corpuscles but houses sensory receptors like Pacinian corpuscles, crucial for detecting deep pressure and vibration.

Option C - Basal epidermis: The basal epidermis, or stratum basale primarily consists of basal cells responsible for renewal and attaching to the basement membrane. Meissner corpuscles aren't present in the epidermis.

Option D - Stratum lucidum:. The stratum lucidum is a thin, translucent layer of the epidermis that is typically found in thick skin areas, such as the palms and soles. It does not contain Meissner corpuscles.

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in –
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Elastic cartilage

  • Elastic cartilage is a specialized type of cartilage found in structures such as the external ear, epiglottis, and eustachian tube. Unlike other types of cartilage, such as hyaline cartilage, elastic cartilage contains a significant amount of elastic fibers in addition to collagen. Type II collagen is the predominant collagen type found in elastic cartilage, providing structural support along with the elastic fibers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bone: Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen type in bone tissue. It provides strength and support to the bone structure.

Option B - Ligament: Type I collagen is the primary collagen type found in ligaments, contributing to their tensile strength.

Option C - Aponeurosis: Similar to ligaments, aponeurosis predominantly consists of Type I collagen, which gives it its strength and resilience.

questions.text: During which developmental week does the heartbeat initiate in the cardiac region?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4th week

  • The heart begins to beat in the 4th week of development. At this stage, the heart has formed and starts contracting, initiating blood circulation within the developing embryo

Incorrect Options

Option A - 2nd week: During the 2nd week of development, the heart is undergoing early stages of formation. However, it does not start beating during this time.

Option C - 6th week: By the 6th week of development, the heart is already beating. This option is incorrect because the heart starts beating earlier, in the 4th week.

Option D - 10th week: By the 10th week of development, the heart has been beating for several weeks. This option is incorrect because it suggests a later timeframe for the initiation of heartbeats.

questions.text: Ureteric bud develops from:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mesonephric duct:

  • The ureteric bud is a structure that arises from the mesonephric duct, also known as Wolffian duct.
  • During embryonic development, the ureteric bud grows out from the mesonephric duct and gives rise to the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting ducts.
  • The ureteric bud interacts with the metanephric mesenchyme to form the kidney.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Metanephros: The definitive kidney (metanephros) develops from the interaction of the ureteric bud and metanephric mesenchyme. But the ureteric bud doesn't originate from the metanephros.

Option C - Pronephros: The pronephros, the most anterior and non-functional part of the embryonic kidney system, regresses early and doesn't form the ureteric bud.

Option D - Genital sinus: The genital sinus contributes to the urogenital system's development, forming the bladder and urethra, but it isn't directly linked to the development of the ureteric bud.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about skin?

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.solution:
Correct Option - A: Dermis is derived from ectoderm: This statement is false. The dermis is not derived from ectoderm but rather from mesoderm. During embryonic development, the dermis is formed from mesodermal cells that migrate into the developing skin.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight: Skin weight varies based on age, sex, and body composition, usually constituting around 7% to 15% of total body weight in adults.

Option C - Epidermis is derived from ectoderm: The epidermis, which is the outermost layer of the skin, is derived from the ectodermal germ layer during embryonic development.

Option D - Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen: The dermis contains collagen fibers, primarily type 1 and type 3, providing strength, support, and elasticity to the skin.

questions.text: A newborn had hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pharyngeal arch 1

  • The first pharyngeal arch, also known as the mandibular arch, is a crucial structure in embryonic development, forming part of the head and neck region. It gives rise to various structures that are essential for the formation of the face and neck.
  • Defects in the development of this arch can result in a condition called mandibulofacial dysostosis or Treacher-Collins syndrome, which is characterized by the same features described in the scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pharyngeal arch 2:. Abnormal development of this arch can result in abnormalities of the ear and hearing, but not the features described in the scenario.

Option C - Pharyngeal arch 3: Abnormal development of this arch can result in problems with swallowing and speech, but not the features described in the scenario.

Option D - Pharyngeal arch 4: Abnormal development of these arches can cause problems with speech and breathing, but not the features described in the scenario.
